Almost as soon as the Oscar nominations were announced this week, many people were pointing out an uncomfortable fact.
Every director nominated is a white male.

That's Deborah Sathe, head of talent development and production at the British nonprofit Film London.
Dare I say it, I was really gutted for the industry.
And I was really gutted personally because I feel there have been some extraordinary films that could have been in there.
She heads Film London's Microwave project, a program that provides mentorship and training to help filmmakers make their first feature on tiny budgets.
Twelve film projects are selected out of more than 100.
The goal is to ensure that half of the filmmakers that end up on that long list are racial or ethnic minorities.
These teams go through an intensive boot camp to sharpen their skills, and in the end, two films are commissioned.
We wanted to have a very aggressive drive to enable our long-lists to reflect the make-up of London.
And both in my experience in television and in film, the talent pool often are those who are in the know.
And I felt that what we needed to do, in order to broaden Microwave's reach, was to run a targeted recruitment campaign across London.
And so we made sure we were talking to all the organizations that had a foothold in communities that sometimes we don't see reflected in the cinema.
And we use social media.
We used theater outreach groups.
And all the sessions that we ran, all the roadshows, all the master classes were full, and it was really, really exciting.
Last year, a successful film came out of the project.

Thousands of pages of reports filled with military slang dashed off in an instant and focusing on the aspects of the war that are arguably the least important, this is how Noah Shachtman sums up most of the WikiLeak documents released earlier this week.
And he should know.
He was embedded in Afghanistan and saw firsthand one of the battles mentioned in the leaked military report.
We'll talk with him in a moment about why the documents did not give us the full picture of the war in Afghanistan and to explain how best to read them.
We also want to hear from our listeners in uniform.
Are you reading the documents?
What do they tell you?
Give us a call at 800-989-8255.
That's our phone number.
Our email address is talk@npr.org.
And to join the conversation, go to the website npr.org and click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Noah Shachtman is the editor of Wired's national security blog, Danger Room, and a nonresident fellow at the Brookings Institution.
We have posted a link to his post, ""My War, WikiLeaked"" at npr.org, click on TALK OF THE NATION.
He joins us now from our bureau in New York.
Noah, nice to have you.
Hey, thanks for having me.
You base your opinion on experience, and you titled your piece, ""What I Saw at Moba Khan."" What exactly did you see there, one of the battles mentioned in the leaked documents?
Right.
So in August of last year, I was in Helmand Province with a group of Marines from Echo Company 2/8 Marines.
And it was - they were involved in some very heavy fighting with local militants there.
And so I spent a bunch of time there as they went out on patrol and almost daily got into firefights.
And many of those firefights were - it turns out, were in the WikiLeaks documents.
And so I decided to go take a look at those WikiLeaks documents and see what they said about those battles.
And as I looked, it became more and more curious to me, the more and more incomplete the reports in WikiLeaks seemed.
So, for example, the WikiLeak document mentions a bomb being dropped and that enemy fire was then suppressed.
Well, I happened to know because I was there that the enemy fire was suppressed for all of 17 minutes and then the fighting started all over again.
Would you say that these facts are simply missed?
Are they errors?
Are they intentional omissions, do you think?
And do - is there a way to even know that?
I don't think there's any lying involved.
I don't think there's any intentional omissions.
I think these are really short, really fast, really compressed reports given from a junior officer to a more senior officer.
You can read them almost like inter-office memos.
And we all know that inter-office memos don't necessarily tell us what happens at the office.
